name: Angkor Wat
shortDescription: The world's largest religious monument, originally built as Hindu temple to Vishnu (1113-1150 CE), later transformed into Buddhist pilgrimage site
fullDescription: Angkor Wat (Khmer: ·û¢·ûÑ·üí·ûÇ·ûö·ûú·ûè·üí·ûè, meaning 'City of Temples') is the largest religious monument in the world, covering approximately 162.6 hectares (402 acres). Built in the early 12th century (1113-1150 CE) by Khmer King Suryavarman II, it was originally constructed as a Hindu temple dedicated to Vishnu, but gradually transformed into a Buddhist temple by the end of the 12th century. The temple complex represents the pinnacle of classical Khmer architecture and has become a symbol of Cambodia, appearing on the national flag. The architecture is designed to represent Mount Meru, the home of the gods in Hindu mythology, with its five towers symbolizing the mountain's five peaks, surrounded by walls representing the mountains at the edge of the world, and the moat representing the cosmic ocean.

geography.realm: Earth / Representation of Mount Meru (divine realm)
geography.location: Siem Reap Province, Cambodia (near Siem Reap city)

inhabitants.name: Vishnu
inhabitants.description: Preserver deity to whom temple was originally dedicated

inhabitants.name: Buddha
inhabitants.description: Later Buddhist images added, temple became Theravada pilgrimage site

events.name: Construction by Suryavarman II
events.description: Khmer King Suryavarman II commissioned and built Angkor Wat over approximately 30 years as state temple and capital

events.name: Transformation to Buddhism
events.description: Gradual conversion from Hindu to Buddhist worship (late 12th-14th centuries), Theravada Buddhism became dominant

events.name: Cham Invasion (1177 CE)
events.description: Cham forces invaded and sacked Angkor, leading to subsequent rebuilding and expansion

events.name: Abandonment of Angkor (1431-1432)
events.description: Thai invasion led Khmer court to abandon Angkor for Phnom Penh, though Buddhist monks maintained temple

events.name: Western 'Rediscovery' (1860)
events.description: Henri Mouhot's published accounts brought Western attention, though temple was never truly 'lost' to local Buddhists

events.name: UNESCO World Heritage (1992)
events.description: Designated World Heritage Site, spurring international restoration efforts and conservation

mythologyContexts.usage: State temple dedicated to Vishnu; cosmic diagram representing Mount Meru and Hindu universe; site depicting major Hindu epics in bas-reliefs

textReferences.context: Churning of Ocean of Milk, Battle of Kurukshetra, Battle of Lanka, Heaven and Hell scenes

textReferences.passage: Battle of Lanka depicted in north gallery
textReferences.context: Rama and Lakshmana vs. Ravana, rescue of Sita

textReferences.passage: Battle of Kurukshetra on south gallery
textReferences.context: Pandavas vs. Kauravas, Krishna as Arjuna's charioteer

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Angkor Wat embodies the Hindu cosmic mountain Mount Meru, with five towers representing its five peaks. The three enclosures symbolize the three levels of heaven, the moat represents the cosmic ocean, and walls represent the mountain ranges at the world's edge. The entire complex functions as a three-dimensional mandala and microcosm of the universe. The Churning of the Ocean of Milk relief symbolizes the cosmic struggle to obtain amrita (immortality), with devas and asuras cooperating despite opposition. Western orientation (unusual for Khmer temples) associates it with Vishnu and death, suggesting funerary function. Apsara carvings represent celestial beauty and divine attendants emerged from the churning. The temple encodes Vedic mathematics, astronomical alignments, and sacred geometry.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Angkor Wat represents the pinnacle of classical Khmer architecture and the power of the Khmer Empire at its zenith. The temple demonstrates sophisticated engineering, artistic achievement, and theological knowledge. Construction required mobilizing massive labor forces and resources, reflecting state power and divine kingship ideology (devaraja cult). The temple preserved Hindu epics and mythology in Southeast Asian context, adapting Indian traditions to local Khmer culture. Angkor Wat's endurance as a living religious site (continuously maintained by Buddhist monks) ensured cultural continuity through centuries of political change.

mythologyContexts.usage: Major Theravada Buddhist pilgrimage site; reinterpreted as Buddhist cosmology; site of active Buddhist worship and monasticism

textReferences.context: Buddha images added throughout galleries, some Hindu deities defaced or replaced

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Buddhist reinterpretation maintained Mount Meru cosmology but oriented it toward Buddhist enlightenment. The temple's vertical progression symbolizes spiritual ascent from earthly realm to enlightenment. Buddha images positioned throughout galleries transform Hindu cosmic narrative into Buddhist path. Continuous monastic presence represents sangha (Buddhist community) maintaining sacred space. The temple's endurance symbolizes dharma's permanence despite political upheaval.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Angkor Wat's transformation to Buddhism demonstrates religious syncretism and continuity in Southeast Asian spirituality. Buddhist monks' continuous maintenance preserved the temple when royal patronage disappeared. Today, Angkor Wat serves as living Buddhist pilgrimage site while preserving Hindu heritage, embodying Cambodia's religious evolution. The temple bridges ancient Hindu kingdom and contemporary Theravada Buddhist nation.

mythologyContexts.usage: National symbol appearing on Cambodian flag; emblem of Khmer cultural identity and historical greatness; source of national pride
mythologyContexts.symbolism: Angkor Wat symbolizes Khmer civilizational achievement, cultural sophistication, and historical greatness. As national symbol, it represents Cambodian identity, resilience, and pride. The temple embodies cultural continuity linking contemporary Cambodia to Angkorian golden age. Its appearance on every flag iteration (including Khmer Rouge) demonstrates its unifying power transcending political divisions.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Angkor Wat is the only building depicted on any national flag, demonstrating its unique status. The temple generates national pride, international recognition, and economic benefits (tourism accounts for 12% of GDP). Angkor Wat shapes Cambodian self-understanding as heir to great civilization. The temple's preservation represents international cooperation and post-conflict recovery after Khmer Rouge genocide. UNESCO designation and restoration efforts position Cambodia in global heritage community.

sources.author: Khmer artisans
sources.passage: 800m of narrative bas-reliefs depicting Hindu epics

sources.text: Angkor Wat: Time, Space and Kingship
sources.author: Eleanor Mannikka
sources.passage: Analysis of astronomical and mathematical symbolism

etymology.origin: From Khmer ·û¢·ûÑ·üí·ûÇ·ûö·ûú·ûè·üí·ûè (√Çngk√¥r V√¥tt): ·û¢·ûÑ·üí·ûÇ·ûö (√¢ngk√¥r) from Sanskrit ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞ (nagara) meaning 'city, capital' + ·ûú·ûè·üí·ûè (v√¥tt) from Pali va·π≠·π≠a or Sanskrit vƒÅ·π≠a meaning 'temple, monastery.' Thus: 'City of Temples' or 'Temple City.'
etymology.development: Originally called 'Preah Pisnulok' (Kingdom of Vishnu). Name 'Angkor Wat' became standard after Buddhist transformation, distinguishing it from other Angkor temples. 'Angkor' applied to entire Khmer capital complex; 'Wat' specified this temple.

originPoint.name: Angkor Wat temple complex
originPoint.description: Angkor Archaeological Park, Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Area: 162.6 hectares. Located 5.5 km north of Siem Reap city.

firstAttestation.description: Construction began under King Suryavarman II in 1113 CE, completed approximately 1150 CE

timelinePosition.context: Built during reign of Suryavarman II, representing apex of Khmer architectural and artistic achievement

keyMoments.significance: Suryavarman II commissions state temple to Vishnu
Temple completed after ~30 years of construction
Gradual conversion from Hindu to Buddhist worship
Khmer court moves to Phnom Penh after Thai invasion
Henri Mouhot brings Western attention (temple never lost to locals)
